The '''gray wolf''' or '''grey wolf''' (''Canis lupus'') is a [[canid]] native to the wilderness and remote areas of [[North America]], [[Eurasia]], and [[North Africa]]. It is the largest member of its family, with males averaging {{convert|43|-|45|kg|abbr=on}}, and females {{convert|36|-|38.5|kg|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|p=11}}</ref> It is similar in general appearance and proportions to a [[German shepherd]],<ref name="z124">{{Harvnb|Sillero-Zubiri|Hoffman|MacDonald|2004|p=124}}</ref> or [[sled dog]], but has a larger head, narrower chest, longer legs, straighter tail, and bigger paws.<ref name="l19" /> Its winter fur is long and bushy, and predominantly a mottled gray in colour, although nearly pure white, red, or brown to black also occur.<ref name="z124" />

Within the [[genus]] ''[[Canis]]'', the gray wolf represents a more [[Generalist and specialist species|specialised]] and progressive form than its smaller cousins (the [[coyote]] and [[golden jackal]]), as demonstrated by its [[Morphology (biology)|morphological]] adaptations to hunting large prey, its more gregarious nature,<ref name="s175">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=175}}</ref> and its highly advanced expressive behavior.<ref name="fox1978" /><ref name="z68" /> It is a [[social animal]], travelling in [[nuclear family|nuclear families]] consisting of a [[mated pair]], accompanied by the pair's adult offspring.<ref name="m1" /> The gray wolf is typically an [[apex predator]] throughout its range, with only [[human]]s and [[tiger]]s<ref name="WoT">Perry, Richard (1964). ''The World of the Tiger''. p. 148. Cassell & Company ltd.</ref><ref name="l29">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=29}}</ref><ref name="s255">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=255}}</ref><ref name="Mech 2003 265">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=265}}</ref> posing a serious threat to it. It feeds primarily on large [[ungulate]]s, though it also eats smaller animals, livestock, carrion, and garbage.<ref name="z128">{{Harvnb|Sillero-Zubiri|Hoffman|MacDonald|2004|p=128}}</ref>

The gray wolf is one of the world's most well known and well researched animals, with probably more books written about it than any other wildlife species.<ref name="mxi">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=xi}}</ref> It has a long history of association with humans, having been despised and hunted in most [[Agriculture|agricultural]] communities due to its attacks on livestock, while conversely being respected by some [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] tribes.<ref name="z128" /> It is the sole ancestor of the [[dog]],<ref>Adam H. Freedman, Ilan Gronau, Rena M. Schweizer, Diego Ortega-Del Vecchyo, Eunjung Han, Pedro M. Silva, Marco Galaverni, Zhenxin Fan, Peter Marx, Belen Lorente-Galdos, Holly Beale, Oscar Ramirez, Farhad Hormozdiari, Can Alkan, Carles Vilà, Kevin Squire, Eli Geffen, Josip Kusak, Adam R. Boyko, Heidi G. Parker, Clarence Lee, Vasisht Tadigotla, Adam Siepel, Carlos D. Bustamante, Timothy T. Harkins, Stanley F. Nelson, Elaine A. Ostrander, Tomas Marques-Bonet, Robert K. (1999). ''Phylogenetic relationships, evolution, and genetic diversity of the domestic dog.'' J Hered. 1999 Jan-Feb;90(1):71-7. http://jhered.oxfordjournals.org/content/90/1/71.full.pdf+html?sid=3e2126f6-f59c-4ab7-8065-0099b6125906</ref><ref>Heidi G. Parker, Lisa V. Kim, Nathan B. Science 21 May 2004: Vol. 304 no. 5674 pp. 1160-1164 DOI: 10.1126/science.1097406</ref> Although the fear of wolves is prevalent in many human societies, the majority of recorded attacks on people have been attributed to animals suffering from [[rabies]]. Non-rabid wolves have attacked and killed people, mainly children, but this is unusual, as wolves are relatively few, live away from people, and have been taught to fear humans by hunters and shepherds.<ref name="lin36">{{Harvnb|Linnell|2002|p=36}}</ref> Hunting and trapping has reduced the species' range to about one third of its original range, though it's still relatively widespread with stable populations. This means that the species is not threatened at a global level, and is therefore classified by the [[IUCN]] as [[Least Concern]].<ref name="iucn">{{IUCN |assessors=Mech, L.D., Boitani, L. (IUCN SSC Wolf Specialist Group) |year=2010 |id=3746 |title=Canis lupus|version=2011.2}}</ref>

==Etymology==
The [[English language|English]] word "wolf" stems from the [[Old English]] ''wulf'', which is itself thought to be derived from the [[Proto-Germanic language|Proto-Germanic]] ''*wulfaz'', from the [[Proto-Indo-European root]] ''*wlqwos''/''*lukwos''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=wolf |title= Online Etymological Dictionary|accessdate=2012-05-19}}</ref> [[Old English literature]] contains several instances of [[Anglo-Saxon kings]] and [[Anglo-Saxon warfare|warriors]] taking on ''wulf'' as a [[prefix]] or [[suffix]] in their names. Examples include Wulfhere, Cynewulf, Ceonwulf, Wulfheard, Earnwulf, Wulfmǣr, Wulfstān and Æthelwulf. Wolf-related names were also common among pre-Christian Germanic warriors: Wolfhroc (Wolf-Frock), Wolfhetan (Wolf Hide), Isangrim (Grey Mask), Scrutolf (Garb Wolf), Wolfgang (Wolf Gait) and Wolfdregil (Wolf Runner).<ref name="marvin74">{{Harvnb|Marvin|2012|pp=74–75}}</ref>

==Evolution and taxonomy==
[[File:Canis lupus timeline.png|thumb|left|Timeline of canids including ''Canis lupus'' in red (Tedford & [[Xiaoming Wang]])]]

===Origins===

====Ancestry====
The species' most likely ancestral candidate is ''[[Canis lepophagus]]'', a small, narrow skulled [[North America]]n canid of the [[Miocene]] era, which may have also given rise to the [[coyote]].<ref name="m239">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=239–45}}</ref> After the extinction of the large bodied ''[[Borophaginae]]'' family, ''C. lepophagus'' developed into a larger, broader-skulled animal. Fossils of this larger form of ''C. lepophagus'' found in northern [[Texas]] may represent the ancestral stock from which true wolves derive.<ref name="evolution">{{cite journal | last1 = Nowak | first1 = R. | year = 1992 | title = Wolves: The great travelers of evolution |journal = International Wolf | volume = 2 | issue = 4| pages = 3–7 }}</ref> The first true wolves began to appear at the end of the [[Blancan|Blancan North American Stage]] and the onset of the early [[Irvingtonian]]. Among them was ''C. priscolatrans'', a small species closely resembling the modern-day [[red wolf]], which colonised [[Eurasia]] by crossing the [[Bering land bridge]]. The new Eurasian ''C. priscolatrans'' population gradually evolved into ''C. mosbachensis'',<ref name="m239" /> which closely resembled modern wolves found in the [[Arabian Peninsula]] and [[South Asia]], which were once distributed in [[Europe]] in the early [[Quaternary glaciation]] until about 500,000 years ago (see ''[[Wolf#Subspecies|Subspecies]]'').<ref name="h38" /> ''C. mosbachensis'' subsequently evolved in the direction of ''C. lupus''.<ref name="m239" /> The earliest ''C. lupus'' remains date back to the [[middle Pleistocene]], and occur in [[Beringia]].<ref>Wang, Xiaoming & Telford, R. H. (2008), ''Dogs: their fossil relatives and evolutionary history'', Columbia University Press, p. 148</ref>{{clear}}

====Subspeciation====
[[File:Arabianwolfjackal.jpg|thumb|The [[Egyptian jackal|African wolf]] (''C. l. lupaster'') represents the oldest extant lineage of the species<ref name="gaubert" />]]
[[MtDNA]] studies have shown that there are at least four distinct gray wolf lineages: the most ancient is that of the African wolf (native to [[North Africa|North]], [[West Africa|West]], and [[East Africa]]), which is thought to have originated as early as the Middle to Late Pleistocene.<ref name="gaubert">{{Cite journal|author=Gaubert P, Bloch C, Benyacoub S, Abdelhamid A, Pagani P, et al|year=2012|title= Reviving the African Wolf ''Canis lupus lupaster'' in North and West Africa: A Mitochondrial Lineage Ranging More than 6,000 km Wide|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=7|issue=8|page=e42740|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0042740|pmid=22900047|pmc=3416759}}</ref> All other lineages occur together in the [[Indian Subcontinent]], the oldest of which is the Himalayan wolf (native to the Himalayan region of eastern [[Kashmir]], [[Himachal Pradesh]], parts of [[Tibet]] and eastern [[Nepal]]), which is thought to have originated 800,000 years ago, when the Himalayan region was going through major geologic and climatic upheaval. The peninsular Indian wolf, ''[[Indian Wolf|C. l. pallipes]]'', likely diverged from the Himalayan wolf 400,000 years ago.<ref name="j+s2004">{{cite journal | last1 = Jhala | first1 = Y. | last2 = Sharma | first2 = D. K. | year = 2004 | title = The Ancient Wolves of India | url = http://www.wolf.org/wolves/news/iwmag/2004/summer/world.pdf | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20090421010138/http://www.wolf.org/wolves/news/iwmag/2004/summer/world.pdf | archivedate = 2009-04-21 | format = PDF | journal = International Wolf | volume = 14 | issue = 2| pages = 15–16 }}</ref><ref name="akrs2007">{{cite journal |author=Aggarwal, R. K., Kivisild, T., Ramadevi, J., Singh, L. |year=2007 |title=Mitochondrial DNA coding region sequences support the phylogenetic distinction of two Indian wolf species |journal=[[Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary Research]] |volume=45 |issue=2 |pages=163–172 |url=http://ccmb.res.in/newccmb/publications/webres/pdf/rka/1.pdf |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20090205155451/http://ccmb.res.in/newccmb/publications/webres/pdf/rka/1.pdf |archivedate=2009-02-05 |doi=10.1111/j.1439-0469.2006.00400.x}}</ref> The youngest wolf lineage in India is represented by ''[[Tibetan wolf|C. l. chanco]]'' (native to the northwestern Himalayan region of Kashmir), which originated 150,000 years ago. This last lineage, known as the [[Holarctic]] clade, expanded into Europe and North America, as shown by it sharing [[genetic marker]]s with domestic dogs, European and North American wolves.<ref name="j+s2004" /><ref name="akrs2007" />

The now extinct Japanese wolves were descended from large Siberian wolves which colonised the [[Korean Peninsula]] and [[Japan]], before it separated from mainland Asia, 20,000 years ago during the Pleistocene. During the Holocene, the [[Tsugaru Strait]] widened and isolated [[Honshu]] from [[Hokkaidō]], thus causing climatic changes leading to the extinction of most large bodied ungulates inhabiting the archipelago. Japanese wolves likely underwent a process of [[island dwarfism]] 7,000–13,000 years ago in response to these climatological and ecological pressures. ''[[Hokkaidō Wolf|C. l. hattai]]'' (formerly native to Hokkaidō) was significantly larger than its southern cousin ''[[Honshu wolf|C. l. hodophilax]]'', as it inhabited higher elevations and had access to larger prey, as well as a continuing genetic interaction with dispersing wolves from Siberia.<ref name="w41">{{Harvnb|Walker|2005|p=41}}</ref>{{clear}}

====Colonization of North America====
''Canis lupus'' colonized North America during the late [[Rancholabrean]] era.<ref name="m245">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=245–250}}</ref> The larger ''[[Canis dirus]]'' was already established there, but it became extinct 8,000 years ago, after the large prey it relied on disappeared. Competition with the newly arrived gray wolf for the smaller and swifter prey that survived may have contributed to its decline. The [[eastern wolf]]/[[red wolf]] appeared to evolve along with the coyote from a common North American ancestor.<ref name=Chambers/> In contrast, the gray wolf evolved in Eurasia and migrated into the northern and western portions of North American.

The North American recolonisation likely occurred in several waves, with the most distinctive populations occurring in the periphery of the range. These populations ''[[Arctic wolf|C. l. arctos]]'' on the high arctic islands, ''[[eastern wolf|C. l. lycaon]]'' in the eastern forests, and ''[[Mexican wolf|C. l. baileyi]]'' in the far south) may represent survivors of early migrations from Eurasia. ''C. l. baileyi'' and ''C. l. lycaon'' display some primitive traits and systematic affinity to one another. Fossil remains from the late Pleistocene of large bodied wolves similar to ''C. l. arctos'' and ''[[tundra wolf|C. l. albus]]'' occur in coastal southern [[California]], indicating that large North American gray wolf subspecies were once widespread, and may have been driven southward by [[glaciation]], though wolves no longer reside there. Fossils of small bodied wolves similar to ''C. l. baileyi'' have been found in a range encompassing Kansas and southern California. This indicates a late Pleistocene population flux, in which large, Arctic forms of wolf moved farther south, with smaller, warmth adapted wolves expanding as the climate moderated.<ref name="m245" />

===Subspecies===
{{Main|Subspecies of Canis lupus}}
{{double image|right|Grauwolf P1130275.jpg|180|Canis lupus female head.JPG|180|[[Eurasian wolf]] (''Canis lupus lupus''), an example of the "northern" wolf clade|[[Arabian wolf]] (''Canis lupus arabs''), an example of the "southern" wolf clade}}
{{As of|2005|uc=on}},<ref name="msw3">{{MSW3 Wozencraft|pages =|id =14000738}}</ref> 37 [[subspecies]] of gray wolf are recognised by [[MSW3]]. There are 2 more subspecies of ''Canis lupus'': the [[domestic dog]] and the [[dingo]].

Wolf subspecies are divided into two categories:
*"'''Northern wolves'''": large-sized, large-brained wolves with strong [[carnassials]] which inhabit North America, Europe and northern Asia.<ref name="h40" />
*"'''Southern wolves'''": native to the Arabian Peninsula, South Asia and possibly North Africa. They are characterised by their smaller size, skull and teeth, and a short and thin [[coat (animal)|coat]] without appreciable underwool.<ref name="p91">{{Harvnb|Pocock|1941|p=91}}</ref> They may represent a [[relict]] population of early wolves, as they closely resemble fossil European wolves.<ref name="h38" /> The rate of changes observed in their DNA sequences date them to about 800,000 years, as opposed to the American and European lineages which stretch back only 150,000.<ref name="sharma+al2003">{{cite pmid|15101402}}</ref> The vocalisations of southern wolves have a higher proportion of short, sharp barking,<ref name="h40">{{Harvnb|Hemmer|1990|p=40}}</ref> and they seldom howl.<ref>{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=15}}</ref> It is likely that dogs and [[dingo]]es stem from this group.<ref name="h40" /><ref>Corbett, L. K. (1995). ''The dingo in Australia and Asia''. Comstock/Cornell, ISBN 0-8014-8264-X</ref>

Phylogenetic comparisons of the [[MtDNA]] sequences of both wolves and [[golden jackal]]s in 2011 demonstrated that the [[Egyptian Jackal|African wolf]], which was once thought to be a golden jackal, is in fact a subspecies of gray wolf.<ref name="Rueness2011">{{cite doi|10.1371/journal.pone.0016385}}</ref>

Wolves in Central and East Asia are intermediate in form and size to northern and southern wolves.<ref name="h38">{{Harvnb|Hemmer|1990|pp=38–40}}</ref> Differences in [[brain size]] are well defined in different wolf populations, with wolves in northern Eurasia having the highest values, North American wolves having slightly smaller brains, and the southern wolves having the smallest (about 5–10% smaller than those of northern wolves).<ref name="h107">{{Harvnb|Hemmer|1990|p=107}}</ref>

====North American wolf species and subspecies====
[[File:Distribution of North American Canis.svg|thumb|left|Modern range of North American ''Canis'':{{legend|#abd099|'''Gray wolf''' (''Canis lupus'')}}{{legend|#f4f499|[[Coyote]] (''Canis latrans'')}}{{legend|#efd6a6|[[Eastern coyote]] (''Canis latrans'' var.)}}{{legend|#bdd0e2|[[Eastern wolf]] (''Canis lycaon'')}}{{legend|#e59999|[[Red wolf]] (''Canis rufus'')}}{{Legend striped|#abd099|#f4f499|Gray wolf and coyote}}]]
[[File:Wolf-evolution.svg|thumb|Chart detailing divergence of North American ''Canis''.]]
[[MSW3]] in 2005 considered the [[eastern wolf|eastern Canada wolf/eastern wolf]] (''Canis lycaon'') of [[Algonquin Provincial Park]] and the [[red wolf]] (''Canis rufus'') of [[North Carolina]] as gray wolf subspecies. These considerations were initially supported by a large mitochondrial [[Single-nucleotide polymorphism|SNP]] study in 2011. The 2011 SNP study suggested that the red wolf and eastern wolf are in fact the results of varying degrees of [[coywolf|wolf–coyote hybridization]] stretching back to only a few centuries.<ref name="genome">{{cite pmid|21566151}}</ref> However, X-Ray analysis of the 16 red wolf specimens used in the SNP study were later shown to be wolf-coyote hybrids via cranial morphometric analysis, rendering the finding that the red wolf was a gray wolf-coyote hybrid inaccurate.<ref name=Beeland>{{cite book |title=The Secret World of Red Wolves |author=T. DeLene Beeland |year=2013 |publisher=University of North Carolina Press |location=Chapel Hill, NC |isbn= 9781469601991 }}</ref> The [[U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service]] (USFWS) still considers the red wolf a valid and separate species from the gray wolf and plans to make no changes to its recovery program.<ref name=USFWSProfile>{{cite web |title=US Fish and Wildlife Species Profile |publisher=USFWS |url=http://ecos.fws.gov/speciesProfile/profile/speciesProfile.action?spcode=A00F |accessdate=2013-12-28 }}</ref> In 2012, Rutledge et al. re-analyzed the data used in the 2011 SNP study and argued that the conclusions were inaccurate due to sampling errors: it sampled only modern red wolf specimens and not historic red wolf specimens from prior to 1900 (when extensive hybridization with coyotes is known to have taken place), and that the authors lumped eastern wolf specimens (which critics from [[Trent University]] warn are of unverified origin) with other Great Lakes wolf specimens, and did not test them separately, which again obfuscated any genetic differences that may have been present.<ref name=Rutledge>{{cite journal |title= Conservation genomics in perspective: A holistic approach to understanding Canis evolution in North America |authors= Linda Y. Rutledge, Paul J. Wilson, Cornelya F.C. Klütsch, Brent R. Patterson, Bradley N. White |journal=Biological Conservation |volume= 155  |year=2012 |pages=186–192 }}</ref>  The authors further note that gray wolves are intolerant of, and do not mate in the wild with coyotes.<ref name=Rutledge/> Another Y-chromosome genetic study in 2012 also argued that the eastern wolf and red wolf are not hybrids but rather are a distinct species from the gray wolf, although eastern and red wolves do intermix with coyotes.<ref name=Y-chromosome>{{cite journal |title=Y-chromosome evidence supports widespread signatures of three-species Canis hybridization in eastern North America |authors=Paul J. Wilson, Linda Y. Rutledge, Tyler J. Wheeldon, Brent R. Patterson & Bradley N. White |journal=Ecology and Evolution |year=2012 |volume=2 |issue=9 |pages=2325–2332 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ece3.301/pdf |accessdate=2013-12-28 }}</ref> The controversy over the eastern wolf's origins is not considered by the scientific community to be laid to rest, although it may be synonymous with the red wolf.<ref name=Chambers>{{cite journal |title=An account of the taxonomy of North American wolves from morphological and genetic analyses |authors=Chambers SM, Fain SR, Fazio B, Amaral M |year=2012 |journal=North American Fauna |volume=77 |pages=1–67 |url=http://www.fwspubs.org/doi/pdf/10.3996/nafa.77.0001 |accessdate=2013-07-02 |doi=10.3996/nafa.77.0001}}</ref> Historical hunting and culling of wolves, along with decimation of the great forest covering the eastern United States, apparently led to invasion of coyotes into eastern North America and hybridization with eastern/red wolves to which coyotes are more closely related genetically. Thus, coyote mitochondrial and nuclear DNA introgressed into fragmented, decimated eastern wolf packs.<ref name=Rutledge2>{{cite journal |title=Intense harvesting of eastern wolves facilitated hybridization with coyotes |authors=Linda Y. Rutledge, Bradley N. White, Jeffrey R. Row & Brent R. Patterson |journal=Ecology and Evolution |volume=2 |issue=1 |year=2012 |pages=19–33 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ece3.61/abstract |accessdate=2013-12-28 }}</ref> They and other authors have postulated that large populations of eastern and red wolves with intact social/pack structures are less likely to interbreed with coyotes.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Canid hybridization: contemporary evolution in human-modified landscapes |journal=Ecology and Evolution |volume=2 |issue=9 |year=2012 |pages=2128–2140 |authors=Astrid V. Stronen, Nathalie Tessier, Hélène Jolicoeur, Paul C. Paquet, Michel Hénault, Mario Villemure, Brent R. Patterson, Tim Sallows, Gloria Goulet and François-Joseph Lapointe |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ece3.335/abstract |accessdate=2013-12-28 }}</ref> The controversy over the red wolf's species status was the subject of a comprehensive USFWS review of the 2011 and 2012 genetics studies, which concluded that there are three separate species of wolf in North America, the red wolf, eastern wolf and gray wolf.<ref name=Chambers/> The USFWS review also concluded that genetic and morphometric analysis supports only three North American subspecies of ''Canis lupus'', which emigrated from Asia in three chronological waves in order:  the [[Mexican gray wolf]] (''C. lupus baileyi''), the plains wolf (''C. lupus nubilus'') and the Arctic wolf (''C. lupus arctos'').<ref name=Chambers/>

In summary, in historical times the gray wolf and coyote ranged generally west of the Mississippi River, while the red wolf and eastern wolf ranged across the forested eastern United States and southeastern Canada. Culling of the red wolf/ eastern wolf associated with European colonization enabled eastward migration of coyotes and hybridization between these species (which share a relatively recent common ancestor) whereas the gray wolf and coyote in the western United States are more distant evolutionary relatives and do not hybridize.<ref name=Rutledge2/> Gray wolves do hybridize with the red wolf/eastern wolf as well as with the now dominant Canis species in eastern North America, the [[coywolf]].

===Domestication===
{{Main|Origin of the domestic dog}}
Morphological comparisons between wolves and domestic dogs have narrowed the likely ancestral subspecies of gray wolf to [[Canis Lupus arabs|Middle Eastern and South Asian wolves]].<ref name="h38" /> This is confirmed by [[Single-nucleotide polymorphism|SNP]] studies done in 2010, which point to the Middle East as the source of most of the genetic diversity in the domestic dog and the most likely origin of domestication events.<ref name="vonHoldt_et_al_2010">{{cite doi|10.1038/nature08837}}</ref> The actual process undergone in domesticating the wolf is still debated. Although it is popularly assumed that dogs originated as a result of [[artificial selection]], the general intractability of adult wolves to human handling has led certain experts to theorise that the domestication process occurred through [[natural selection]], when [[Mesolithic]] human communities began building permanent settlements in which a new [[ecological niche]] ([[midden]]s and [[landfill]]s) was opened to wolves. These wolves would have formed a [[commensalism|commensal relationship]] with humans, feeding on their waste over many generations, with natural selection favouring assertive wolves with shorter [[flight distance]]s in human presence, and causing physical changes related to the redundancy of features adapted for hunting big game.<ref name="c39">{{Harvnb|Coppinger|Coppinger|2001|pp=39–67}}</ref>

Although dogs are the wolf's closest relative (the [[genetic divergence]] between gray wolves and dogs is only 1.8%, as opposed to over 4% between gray wolves, [[Ethiopian wolf|Ethiopian wolves]] and [[coyote]]s),<ref name="m225">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=225}}</ref> comparative studies on dog and wolf behaviour and anatomy have shown that dog physiology and most dog behaviours are comparable to those of young wolves, an example of [[neoteny]] and [[pedomorphism]].<ref name="h83">{{Harvnb|Hemmer|1990|p=83}}</ref> The [[Auditory bulla|tympanic bullae]] are large, convex and almost spherical in wolves, while the bullae of dogs are smaller, compressed and slightly crumpled.<ref name="mech" /> Compared to equally sized dogs, wolves tend to have 20% larger skulls and 10% bigger brains.<ref name="c54">{{Harvnb|Coppinger|Coppinger|2001|pp=54–5}}</ref> This reduction lies in the parts of the brain that deal with sense impressions.<ref name="z9">{{Harvnb|Zimen|1981|p=9}}</ref> The teeth of wolves are also proportionately larger than those of dogs; [[premolar]]s and [[Molar (tooth)|molar]]s of wolves are much less crowded, and have more complex [[Cusp (dentistry)|cusp]] patterns.<ref>Clutton-Brock, Juliet (1987), ''A Natural History of Domesticated Mammals'', British Museum (Natural History), p. 24, ISBN 0-521-34697-5</ref> Dogs lack a functioning [[pre-caudal gland]], and most enter [[estrus]] twice yearly, unlike wolves which only do so once annually.<ref name="m257">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=257}}</ref>{{clear}}

===Hybridization===
{{See also|Canid hybrids}}

====Hybridization with dogs====
{{Main|Wolfdog|black wolf}}
[[File:Llop.jpg|thumb|Arctic wolf/[[Alaskan malamute]] hybrid, Lobo Park, [[Antequera]], [[Spain]]]]
Although dogs and wolves are genetically very close, and have shared vast portions of their ranges for millennia, the two generally do not voluntarily interbreed in the wild,<ref name="m257" /> though [[Lone wolf (trait)|lone wolves]] may fraternise with [[guard dog|guard]] or [[herding dogs]] as surrogate pack members.<ref name="g10">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|p=10}}</ref> They can produce viable offspring, with all subsequent generations being fertile.<ref name="m257" /> In North America, black colored wolves acquired their coloration from wolf-dog hybridization, which occurred 10,000–15,000 years ago.<ref name="black" /> Although wolf-dog hybridisation in Europe has raised concern among conservation groups fearing for the wolf's purity, an analysis on the [[mtDNA]] sequences show that introgression of dog genes into European wolf populations does not pose a significant threat. Also, as wolf and dog [[mating season]]s do not fully coincide, the likelihood of wild wolves and dogs mating and producing surviving offspring is small.<ref name="vila">{{Cite journal|author=Vilà, Carles and Wayne, Robert K.|jstor=2641580 |title=Hybridization between Wolves and Dogs|journal=Conservation Biology|pages =195–198|volume= 13|issue=1|year= 1997|doi=10.1046/j.1523-1739.1999.97425.x}}</ref> Like pure wolves, hybrids breed annually, though their mating season occurs three months earlier, with pups mostly being born in the winter period, thus lessening their chances of survival.<ref name="m257" />

Although it is popularly believed that some [[Inuit]] tribes mate their sled dogs to wolves in order to improve their stamina, this is probably untrue, as wolf hybrids are generally unable to cooperate effectively in pulling harnesses, and their stamina is much less than that of sled dogs.<ref name="c186">{{Harvnb|Coppinger|Coppinger|2001|p=186}}</ref> The [[captive breeding]] of wolf-dog hybrids has proliferated in the USA, with 300,000 such animals being present there.<ref name="m257" /> The most commonly used dog breeds for this purpose are of the [[spitz]] group.<ref name="DEFRA">Cusdin, P. A. (2000) [http://archive.defra.gov.uk/wildlife-pets/wildlife/protect/documents/dwa-wolfdogs.pdf ''The Keeping of Wolf-Hybrids in Great Britain'', ''Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals'']</ref> At least two wolf-dog breeds have been created in Europe, the [[Saarlooswolfhond]] and the [[Czechoslovakian Wolfdog]], both by crossing wolves with German shepherds.<ref name="DEFRA" />

====Hybridization with coyotes and golden jackals====
{{Main|Coywolf|Canis latrans "var."|eastern wolf|red wolf}}
Numerous genetic studies indicate that eastern wolves have hybridized with coyotes in varying degrees in different areas. Studies on [[mtDNA]] and [[microsatellite (genetics)|microsatellite loci]] indicate that wolves have hybridized extensively with coyotes in the northeastern [[USA]] and southeastern [[Canada]], with the frequency of coyote [[haplotype]]s in wolves tending to increase to the east, from 50% in [[Minnesota]], to 100% in southern [[Quebec]].<ref name="m234">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=234}}</ref> [[Canis latrans "var."|These hybrids]] called "coywolves" (or "coywolf" for singular) are smaller than wolves, and hold smaller territories, but are in turn larger and hold more extensive territories than coyotes.<ref name="easterncoyote">{{cite journal | last1 = Way | first1 = Jonathan G. | year = 2008 | title = Eastern Coyote: Coyote, Wolf, or Hybrid? | url = http://www.projectcoyote.org/newsreleases/news_eastern.html | journal = International Wolf | volume = 18 | issue = 3| pages = 7–10 }}</ref> These coywolves appear to have resulted from hybridization of coyotes migrating east over the Great Lakes with eastern wolves or hybrids between eastern wolves and Great Plains wolves, and are larger and better adapted to habitat and prey south of the moose-dominated "North Woods" of New England.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Taxonomic Implications of Morphological and Genetic Differences in Northeastern Coyotes (Coywolves) (Canis latrans × C. lycaon), Western Coyotes (C. latrans), and Eastern Wolves (C. lycaon or C. lupus lycaon) |author=Jonathan G. Way |journal=The Canadian Field-Naturalist |volume=127 |issue=1 |date=January–March 2013 |url=http://www.easterncoyoteresearch.com/downloads/CoywolfTaxonomy&BodyMassCFN2013.pdf |accessdate=2014-02-09 }}</ref>

[[File:07-03-23RedWolfAlbanyGAChehaw.jpg|thumb|left|The [[red wolf]], a [[coyote]] with distant wolf ancestry<ref name="genome" />]]

In an evolutionary biology research conducted by a team of researchers in the Uppsala University, analysis of control region haplotypes of the mitochondrial DNA and sex chromosomes from Mexican wolves, a critically endangered subspecies of the gray wolf once nearly driven to extinction in the wild, confirmed the presence of coyote markers in some of the wolves.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Hybridization among Three Native North American Canis Species in a Region of Natural Sympatry |authors=Frank Hailer, Jennifer A. Leonard |journal=PLoS One |year=2008 |url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0003333 |accessdate=2014-02-09 }}</ref> The study suggests that when the subspecies became depleted in the wild from persecution, female coyotes in the south managed to interbreed with some of the male wolves of the remnant wild Mexican wolf populations with the female hybrids backcrossing with other male wolves. Analysis on the haplotype of some coyotes from Texas also detected the presence of male wolf introgression such as Y chromosomes from the gray wolves in the southern coyotes. In an extremely rare case, the study found that one coyote out of the seventy individuals from Texas was discovered to carry a mtDNA haplotype derived from a female Mexican wolf implicating that a male coyote had managed to breed with a female grey wolf in the wild. The Mexican wolves may be the only gray wolf subspecies in the southern States besides the domestic and feral dogs to have hybridized with coyotes. However, their findings may be better explained by red wolf-coyote hybrids mating with gray wolves, since gray wolves mate with red wolves but almost never with coyotes.<ref name=Chambers/>

In tests performed on a sample from a taxidermied carcass of what was initially labelled as a [[chupacabra]], mtDNA analysis conducted by Texas State University professor Michael Forstner showed that it was a coyote. Subsequent analysis by a veterinary genetics laboratory team at the University of California, Davis concluded that, based on the sex chromosomes, the male animal was a coyote–wolf [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrid]] sired by a male [[Mexican wolf]].<ref name=Bionews-tx>http://bionews-tx.com/news/2013/09/01/texas-state-university-researcher-helps-unravel-mystery-of-texas-blue-dog-claimed-to-be-chupacabra/</ref><ref>http://www.victoriaadvocate.com/news/2008/oct/31/sl_chupa_12/</ref> It has been suggested that the hybrid animal was afflicted with [[sarcoptic mange]], which would explain its hairless and blueish appearance.

[[File:Westerncoywolf.png|thumb|A hybrid brought out in captivity between a female western coyote and a male western gray wolf<ref name="plosone.org">http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0088861</ref>]]

In 2013, a captive breeding experiment conducted in the U.S. Department of Agriculture Wildlife Services National Wildlife Research Center Predator Research Facility in Logan, Utah between gray wolves from British Columbia and western coyotes produced six hybrids, making this the very first hybridization case between pure coyotes and northwestern gray wolves.<ref>http://www.usgs.gov/newsroom/article.asp?ID=3812#.UxFuc_ldWwQ</ref> The experiment used artificial insemination and was aimed with the intention of determining whether or not if the sperms of the larger gray wolves in the west are capable of fertilizing the egg cells in the western coyotes. Aside from the historical hybridizations between coyotes and the smaller Mexican gray wolves in the south as well as with eastern wolves and red wolves, grays wolves from the northwestern USA and western provinces of Canada are not known to interbreed with coyotes in the wild, thus prompted the experiment. The six hybrids brought out from this captive breeding included four males and two females. These coywolves were shortly rehomed at the Wildlife Science Center in Forest Lake, Minnesota where they have been living under the care of professional wildlife caretakers from there on. At six months of age, the hybrids were closely monitored and were shown to display both physical and behaviourial characteristics from both species as well as some physical similarities to the eastern wolves, whose status as a distinct wolf species or as a genetically distinct subspecies of the gray wolf is still being debated among various researchers.<ref name="plosone.org"/> Regardless, the result of this experiment concluded that northwestern gray wolves, much like the eastern wolves, red wolves, Mexican wolves, and domestic dogs, are indeed capable of hybridizing with coyotes. Although this hybridization was brought out through artificial insemination due to the gray wolves' natural hostility towards coyotes which would have caused difficulties in attempting to naturally breed the two rival species together.

Although hybridization between wolves and golden jackals has never been observed, evidence of such occurrences was discovered through mtDNA analysis on jackals in [[Senegal]]<ref name="gaubert" /> and [[Bulgaria]].<ref name="moura">{{Cite journal|author=Moura, Andre E., et al|year=2013|title= Unregulated hunting and genetic recovery from a severe population decline: the cautionary case of Bulgarian wolves|journal=Conservation Genetics|volume=14|issue=|page=|doi=    10.1007/s10592-013-0547-y}}</ref>

==Physical description==
[[File:Lupusskeleton.JPG|right|thumb|Wolf skeleton, ''Museo del Lupo'', [[Abruzzo National Park]], Italy]]

===Anatomy===
{{see also|Dog anatomy}}

The gray wolf is a slender, powerfully built animal with a large, deeply descending [[ribcage]] and a sloping back. Its abdomen is pulled in, and its neck heavily muscled. Its limbs are long and robust, with comparatively small paws.<ref name="s166">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=166}}</ref> The front paws have five toes each, while the back paws have four. The forelimbs are seemingly pressed into the chest, with the elbows pointed inward, and the feet outward, thus allowing both fore and hind limbs on the same side to swing in the same line. The wolf's legs are moderately longer than those of other canids. This enables the animal to move swiftly, and allows it to overcome the deep snow that covers most of its geographical range.<ref name="mech13">{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|p=13}}</ref> Females tend to have narrower muzzles and foreheads, thinner necks, slightly shorter legs and less massive shoulders than males.<ref name="l23">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=23}}</ref> Compared to its smaller cousins (the [[coyote]] and [[golden jackal]]), the gray wolf is larger and heavier, with a broader snout, shorter ears, a shorter torso and longer tail.<ref name="gaubert" /><ref name="mech">{{cite journal | last1 = Mech | first1 = D. L. | year = 1974 | title = Canis lupus | url = http://www.science.smith.edu/msi/pdf/i0076-3519-037-01-0001.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Mammalian Species | volume = 37 | issue = 37| pages = 1–6 | doi = 10.2307/3503924 }}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=129}}</ref>{{clear}}
[[File:Wolf on the move.jpg|thumb|left|[[Northwestern wolf]] (''C. l. occidentalis'') trotting, [[Denali National Park]]. When moving, the wolf generally places its hind paws in the tracks made by the front paws.<ref name="mech13"/>]]

The gray wolf's head is large and heavy, with a wide forehead, strong jaws and a long, blunt muzzle. The ears are relatively small and triangular.<ref name="s166" /> The teeth are heavy and large, being better suited to crushing bone than those of other extant canids, though not as specialised as those found in [[hyena]]s.<ref name="therrien">{{cite doi|10.1017/S0952836905007430}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=112}}</ref> The [[canine teeth]] are robust and relatively short (26&nbsp;mm).<ref name="mech" /> The wolf can exert a crushing pressure of perhaps {{convert|10340|kPa|abbr=on}} compared to {{convert|5200|kPa|abbr=on}} for a [[German shepherd]]. This force is sufficient to break open most bones.<ref>{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=26}}</ref> In cold climates, the wolf can reduce the flow of blood near its skin to conserve body heat. The warmth of the footpads is regulated independently of the rest of the body, and is maintained at just above [[frostbite|tissue-freezing]] point where the pads come in contact with ice and snow.<ref>{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|pp=19–20}}</ref>

The gray wolf usually carries its head at the same level as the back, raising it only when alert.<ref name="s166" /> It usually travels at a loping pace, placing its paws one directly in front of the other. This gait can be maintained for hours at a rate of 8–9&nbsp;km/h,<ref name="m32">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=32}}</ref> and allows the wolf to cover great distances. On bare paths, a wolf can quickly achieve speeds of 50–60&nbsp;km/h. The gray wolf has a running gait of 55 to 70&nbsp;km/h, can leap 5 metres horizontally in a single bound, and can maintain rapid pursuit for at least 20 minutes.<ref>Nowak, Ronald M; and Paradiso, John L. (1983). ''Walker's Mammals of the World''. 4th ed. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. p.953.</ref> A running wolf holds its head slightly low and cocked to one side, directing one ear forward and the other back. This posture allows the wolf to continually make use of its exceptional hearing.<ref name="s260">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=260}}</ref>{{clear}}

===Dimensions===
[[File:Volkshakal.JPG|thumb|Gray wolf and [[golden jackal]] exhibit at [[Zoological Museum of the Zoological Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences|The Museum of Zoology]], [[St. Petersburg]]. Note the wolf's larger size and broader muzzle.]]
The gray wolf is the largest extant member of the ''[[Canidae]]'', excepting certain large breeds of domestic dog.<ref name="mech" /> Gray wolf weight and size can vary greatly worldwide, tending to increase proportionally with latitude as predicted by [[Bergmann's Rule]],<ref name="s197">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=197}}</ref> with the large wolves of [[Alaska]] and [[Canada]] sometimes weighing 3–6 times more than their [[Middle East]]ern and [[South Asia]]n cousins.<ref>Hunter, Luke & Barrett, Priscilla (2011), ''A Field Guide to the Carnivores of the World'', New Holland Publishers, p. 100, ISBN 978-1-84773-346-7</ref> On average, adult wolves measure 105–160&nbsp;cm (41–63&nbsp;in) in length and 80–85&nbsp;cm (32–34&nbsp;in) in shoulder height.<ref name="s174" /> The tail is ⅔ the length of the head and body,<ref name="p80">{{Harvnb|Pocock|1941|p=80}}</ref> measuring 29–50&nbsp;cm (11–20&nbsp;in) in length. The ears are {{convert|90|-|110|mm|in}} in height, and the hind feet are 220–250&nbsp;mm.<ref name="s174">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=174}}</ref> The skull averages 9–11&nbsp;inches in length, and 5–6&nbsp;inches wide.<ref name="mech14">{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|p=14}}</ref> Wolf weight varies geographically; on average, European wolves may weigh {{Convert|38.5|kg|lb}}, North American wolves {{Convert|36|kg|lb}} and Indian and Arabian wolves {{Convert|25|kg|lb}}.<ref name="l19">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=19}}</ref> Females in any given wolf population typically weigh 5–10&nbsp;lbs less than males.<ref name="l18">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=18}}</ref>

Wolves weighing over 54&nbsp;kg (120&nbsp;lbs) are uncommon, though exceptionally large individuals have been recorded in Alaska, Canada,<ref name="l18" /> and the [[former Soviet Union]].<ref name="s174" /><ref name="g35">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|p=35}}</ref> The heaviest recorded gray wolf in North America was killed on 70 Mile River in east-central Alaska on July 12, 1939 and weighed {{Convert|79.4|kg|lb}},<ref name="l18" /> while the heaviest recorded wolf in Eurasia was killed after World War II in [[Kobeliaky]], [[Poltava Oblast|Poltavskij Region]], [[Ukrainian SSR]], and weighed {{Convert|86|kg|lb}}.<ref name="g35" />{{clear}}

===Fur===
[[File:Black and White Wolves.jpg|thumb|left|Black and white-furred wolves, [[Pays de la Loire]]]]
The gray wolf has very dense and fluffy winter fur, with short underfur and long, coarse [[guard hair]]s.<ref name="s166" /> Most of the underfur and some of the guard hairs are shed in the spring and grow back in the autumn period.<ref name="l19" /> The longest hairs occur on the back, particularly on the front quarters and neck. Especially long hairs are found on the shoulders, and almost form a crest on the upper part of the neck. The hairs on the cheeks are elongated and form tufts. The ears are covered in short hairs which strongly project from the fur. Short, elastic and closely adjacent hairs are present on the limbs from the [[elbow]]s down to the [[calcaneal tendon]]s.<ref>{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=167}}</ref> The winter fur is highly resistant to cold; wolves in northern climates can rest comfortably in open areas at −40° by placing their muzzles between the rear legs and covering their faces with their tail. Wolf fur provides better insulation than dog fur, and does not collect ice when warm breath is condensed against it.<ref name="l19" /> In warm climates, the fur is coarser and scarcer than in northern wolves.<ref name="s166" /> Female wolves tend to have smoother furred limbs than males, and generally develop the smoothest overall coats as they age. Older wolves generally have more white hairs in the tip of the tail, along the nose and on the forehead. The winter fur is retained longest in lactating females, though with some hair loss around their nipples.<ref name="l23" /> Hair length on the middle of the back is 60–70&nbsp;mm. Hair length of the guard hairs on the shoulders generally does not exceed 90&nbsp;mm, but can reach 110–130&nbsp;mm.<ref>{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=169}}</ref>

Coat colour ranges from almost pure white through various shades of blond, cream, and ochre to grays, browns, and blacks.<ref name="l21">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=21}}</ref> Variation in fur color tends to increase in higher latitudes.<ref name="mech16">{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|pp=16–17}}</ref> Differences in coat colour between sexes are largely absent,<ref>{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=168}}</ref> though females may have redder tones.<ref>{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=22}}</ref> Fur color doesn't seem to serve any [[camouflage]] purpose, with some experts concluding that the blended colors have more to do with emphasizing certain gestures during interaction.<ref>{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=45}}</ref> [[Black wolf (animal)|Black coloured wolves]] (which occur through [[wolf-dog hybrid]]isation) rarely occur in Eurasia, where interactions with domestic dogs have been reduced over the past thousand years due to the depletion of wild wolf populations. Black specimens are more common in North America, with about half the wolves in Yellowstone National Park being black.<ref name="black">{{cite doi|10.1126/science.1165448 }}</ref>{{clear}}

===Sensory abilities===
The gray wolf's [[sense of smell]] is relatively weakly developed when compared to that of some [[hunting dog]] breeds, being able to detect carrion upwind no farther than 2–3&nbsp;km. Because of this, it rarely manages to capture hidden hares or birds, though it can easily follow fresh tracks. Its [[auditory perception]] is sharper than that of the [[fox]],<ref name="s242">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|pp=242–244}}</ref> being able to hear up to a frequency of 26&nbsp;kHz,<ref name="l43" /> which is sufficient to register the fall of leaves in the autumn period.<ref name="s242" /> The [[urban legend]] that wolves fear the sound of [[string instrument]]s may have a basis in fact, as captive wolves have been shown to exhibit signs of intense distress when hearing low minor chords.<ref name="cornish">{{Cite journal|last1=Cornish|first1=Charles J.|last2=Selous|first2=Frederick C.|last3=Johnston|first3=Harry H.|last4=Maxwell|first4=Herbert|url=http://www.archive.org/stream/livinganimalsofw01cornrich#page/n7/mode/2up|title=The living animals of the world; a popular natural history with one thousand illustrations|publisher=Dodd, Mead and Company |year=1902|ref=harv|accessdate=2013-01-25}}</ref> Its [[night vision]] exceeds that of other Canids.<ref name="s242" />

==Behaviour==
{{See also|Dog behavior}}

===Social and territorial behaviors===
[[File:Wolf pack in Yellowstone NP.jpg|thumb|[[Northwestern wolf]] (''C. l. occidentalis'') pack in [[Yellowstone National Park]]]]
Although [[Lone wolf (trait)|some wolves are solitary]], most are highly gregarious animals.<ref name="f495">{{Harvnb|Feldhamer|Thompson|Chapman|2003|p=495}}</ref> The basic social unit of a wolf [[Pack (canine)|pack]] is the mated pair, accompanied by the pair's adult offspring.{{efn|In the past, the prevailing view on wolf packs was that they consisted of individuals vying with each other for dominance, with dominant wolves being referred to as the "alpha" male and female, and the subordinates as "beta" and "omega" wolves. This terminology was first used in 1947 by Rudolf Schenkel of the [[University of Basel]], who based his findings on researching the behavior of captive wolves. This view on wolf pack dynamics was later popularized by [[L. David Mech]] in his 1970 book ''The Wolf''. He formally disavowed this terminology in 1999, explaining that it was heavily based on the behavior of captive packs consisting of unrelated individuals, an error reflecting the once prevailing view that wild pack formation occurred in winter among independent wolves. Later research on wild wolves revealed that the pack is usually a family consisting of a breeding pair and its offspring of the previous 1–3 years.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Mech, L. David. |year=1999|url=http://www.npwrc.usgs.gov/resource/2000/alstat/alstat.htm |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20051214072331/http://www.npwrc.usgs.gov/resource/2000/alstat/alstat.htm |archivedate=2005-12-14 |title=Alpha status, dominance, and division of labor in wolf packs|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume= 77|pages=1196–1203|doi=10.1139/z99-099|issue=8}}</ref>}} In ideal conditions, the mated pair produces pups every year, with such offspring typically staying in the pack for 10–54 months before dispersing.<ref name="m1">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=1–2}}</ref> The average pack consists of a family of 5–11 animals (1–2 adults, 3–6 juveniles and 1–3 yearlings),<ref name="s222">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=222}}</ref> or sometimes two or three such families,<ref name="f495" /> with exceptionally large packs consisting of 42 wolves being known.<ref name="m2" /> Triggers for dispersal include the onset of [[sexual maturity]] and competition within the pack for food.<ref name="m12">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=12–13}}</ref> The distance travelled by dispersing wolves varies widely - some stayed in the vicinity of the parental group, while other individuals have been recorded travelling great distances of 390&nbsp;km, 206&nbsp;km, and 670&nbsp;km from their natal packs.<ref>Nowak, Ronald M; and Paradiso, John L. Walker's Mammals of the World. 4th ed. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press; 1983. p953</ref> A new pack is usually founded by an unrelated male and female, travelling together in search of an area devoid of other hostile packs.<ref name="m38">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=38}}</ref> Wolf packs rarely adopt other wolves into their fold, and typically kill them. In the rare cases where other wolves are adopted, the adoptee is almost invariably an immature animal (1–3 years of age) unlikely to compete for breeding rights with the mated pair. In some cases, a lone wolf is adopted into a pack to replace a deceased breeder.<ref name="m2">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=2–3, 28}}</ref> During times of ungulate abundance (migration, calving etc.), different wolf packs may temporarily join forces.<ref name="s225">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=225}}</ref>

Wolves are highly [[territory (animal)|territorial]] animals, and generally establish territories far larger than they require to survive in order to assure a steady supply of prey. Territory size depends largely on the amount of prey available and the age of the pack's pups, tending to increase in size in areas with low prey populations<ref name="jedrzejewski">{{Cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.0906-7590.2007.04826.x|author=Jędrzejewski W, Schmidt K, Theuerkauf J, Jędrzejewska B, Kowalczyk R. |year=2007|title=Territory size of wolves Canis lupus: linking local (Białowieża Primeval Forest, Poland) and Holarctic-scale patterns|journal=Ecography|volume= 30|pages= 66–76}}</ref> or when the pups reach the age of 6 months, thus having the same nutritional needs as adults.<ref name="m19">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=19–26}}</ref> Wolf packs travel constantly in search of prey, covering roughly 9% of their territory per day (average 25&nbsp;km/d or 15&nbsp;mi/d). The core of their territory is on average {{convert|35|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}, in which they spend 50% of their time.<ref name="jedrzejewski" /> Prey density tends to be much higher in the territory's surrounding areas, though wolves tend to avoid hunting in the fringes of their territory unless desperate, due to the possibility of fatal encounters with neighboring packs.<ref>{{cite doi|10.1126/science.198.4314.320}}</ref> The smallest territory on record was held by a pack of six wolves in northeastern Minnesota, which occupied an estimated {{Convert|33|km2|abbr=on}}, while the largest was held by an Alaskan pack of ten wolves encompassing a {{Convert|6,272|km2|abbr=on}} area.<ref name="m19" /> Wolf packs are typically settled, and usually only leave their accustomed ranges during severe food shortages.<ref name="s245">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=245}}</ref>

Wolves defend their territories from other packs through a combination of [[#Olfactory|scent marking]], direct attacks and howling (see [[Wolf#Communication|Communication]]). Scent marking is used for territorial advertisement, and involves urination, defecation and ground scratching.<ref>{{cite doi|10.1002/zoo.1430050103}}</ref><ref>{{cite doi|10.1139/z91-240}}</ref><ref>{{cite doi|10.1016/0018-506X(90)90038-Y}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|author=Harrington, Fred H. |jstor=4534102|title= Urine-Marking and Caching Behavior in the Wolf|journal=Behaviour|volume= 76|issue=3/4 |year=1981|pages= 280–288|doi=10.1163/156853981X00112}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|author=Zub, K., Theuerkauf, J., Jędrzejewski, W., Jędrzejewska, B., Schmidt, K., Kowalczyk R.|jstor=4536049|title= Wolf Pack Territory Marking in the Białowieża Primeval Forest (Poland)|journal=Behaviour|volume= 140|issue= 5 |year=2003|pages= 635–648|doi=10.1163/156853903322149478}}</ref> Scent marks are generally left every 240 metres throughout the territory on regular travelways and junctions. Such markers can last for 2–3 weeks,<ref name="m19" /> and are typically placed near rocks, boulders, trees or the skeletons of large animals.<ref name="s226">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=226}}</ref> When scent marking and howling fail to deter strange wolf packs from entering another's territory, violent interactions can ensue.<ref name="m19" /> Territorial fights are among the principal causes of wolf mortality: one study on wolf mortality in Minnesota and the [[Denali National Park and Preserve]] concluded that 14–65% of wolf deaths were due to predation by other wolves.<ref>Mech, David L., Adams, Layne G., Meier, Tomas J., Burch, John W., & Dale, Bruce W. (2003), ''The Wolves of Denali'', University of Minnesota Press, p. 163, ISBN 0816629595</ref>

{{anchor|Copulation}}

===Reproduction and development===
{{commons category|Wolves mating}}
{{See also|Canine reproduction|Animal sexual behavior#Canidae}}
[[File:Korean wolves mating (cropped).jpg|left|thumb|Wolves mating, [[Tama zoo]]]]
The gray wolf is generally [[monogamous]], with mated pairs usually remaining together for life, unless one of the pair dies. Upon the death of one mated wolf, pairs are quickly re-established. Since males often predominate in any given wolf population, unpaired females are a rarity.<ref name="s248">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=248}}</ref> If a dispersing male wolf is unable to establish a territory or find a mate, he mates with the daughters of already established breeding pairs from other packs. Such wolves are termed "[[Casanova]] wolves" and, unlike males from established packs, they do not form [[pair bond]]s with the females they mate with. Some wolf packs may have multiple breeding females this way, as is the case in [[History of Wolves in Yellowstone|Yellowstone National Park]].<ref>Smith, Douglas W. (2006) ''Decade of the Wolf: Returning the Wild to Yellowstone'', Lyons Press, ISBN 1-59228-886-3</ref> Gray wolves also practice [[Alloparenting|alloparental care]], in which a wolf pair may adopt the pup or pups of another. This might take place if the original parents die or are for some reason separated from them. This behavior is common and is seen in many other animal species like the elephant.<ref>Riedman, Marianne L. (December 1982). “The Evolution of Alloparental Care in Mammals and Birds”. The Quarterly Review of Biology 57 (4): 405-435</ref>

In addition to heterosexual behavior, homosexual behavior has been observed in wolves.<ref name="Roughgarden2004">{{cite book|author=Roughgarden, Joan |title=Evolution's rainbow: diversity, gender, and sexuality in nature and people|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=dASsUFtN57sC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=wolves&f=false|year=2004|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-24073-5|pages=140–}}</ref> Male wolves often [[Homosexual behavior in animals|mount each other]] when the highest ranking female in the pack comes into heat.<ref name="Bagemihl2000">{{cite book|author=Bruce Bagemihl|title=Biological Exuberance: Animal Homosexuality and Natural Diversity|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=tmFJ1LhbVWcC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=wolves&f=false|date=10 April 2000|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=978-1-4668-0927-7}}</ref>

The age of first breeding in wolves depends largely on environmental factors: when food is plentiful, or when wolf populations are heavily managed, wolves can rear pups at younger ages in order to better exploit abundant resources. This is further demonstrated by the fact that captive wolves have been known to breed as soon as they reach 9–10 months, while the youngest recorded breeding wolves in the wild were 2 years old. Females are capable of producing pups every year, with one [[litter (animal)|litter]] annually being the average. Unlike the coyote, the gray wolf never reaches [[Menopause|reproductive senescence]].<ref name="m175">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=175}}</ref> [[Estrus]] typically occurs in late winter, with older, multiparous females entering estrus 2–3 weeks earlier than younger females.<ref name="s248" /> When [[sexually receptive|receptive]], the female averts the base of her tail to one side, exposing the [[Canine female reproductive system|vulva]].<ref name="MechBoitani2003" /> During mating, the male's [[bulbus glandis]] expands, locking the pair into a [[copulatory tie]]<ref name="MechBoitani2003">{{cite book|author1=Mech, L. David and Boitani, Luigi |title=Wolves: Behavior, Ecology, and Conservation|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=_mXHuSSbiGgC&pg=PA44|year=2003|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-51696-7|pages=44–}}</ref><ref name="Mech2003">{{cite book|author=Mech, L. David |title=The Wolves of Minnesota: Howl in the Heartland|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=TVJV4hJ8-xgC&pg=PA77|year= 2003|publisher=Voyageur Press|isbn=978-0-89658-509-6|pages=77–}}</ref><ref name="Corporation2010">{{cite book|title=Mammal Anatomy: An Illustrated Guide|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=mTPI_d9fyLAC&pg=PA252|year= 2010|publisher=Marshall Cavendish|isbn=978-0-7614-7882-9|pages=252–}}</ref> which may last 5–36 minutes.<ref name="Corporation2010" /><ref name="Long1996">{{cite book|author=Long, Kim |title=Wolves: A Wildlife Handbook|url=http://books.google.com/?id=DwcrXurTJpEC&q=penis|year=1996|publisher=Johnson Books|isbn=978-1-55566-158-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Illustrated Encyclopedia of North American Mammals: A Comprehensive Guide to Mammals of North America|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=VxK4KWrGn2cC&pg=PT977|year=2009|publisher=MobileReference|isbn=978-1-60501-279-7|pages=977–}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Coleman, Jon T. |title=Vicious: Wolves and Men in America|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=MQ_8WS89N3wC&pg=PA26#v=onepage&q=penis&f=false|year=2004|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-13337-0|pages=26–}}</ref> Wolves are able to separate from a copulatory tie more readily than domestic dogs.<ref name="Busch2007">{{cite book|author=Busch, Robert H. |title=The Wolf Almanac: Celebration of Wolves and Their World|url=http://books.google.com/?id=iUVJsGY9Q-8C&pg=PA79|year= 2007|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=978-1-59921-069-8|pages=79–}}</ref> When a male wolf ejaculates, his final [[pelvic thrust]] may be slightly prolonged.<ref name="MechBoitani2010">{{cite book|author= Mech, L. David and Boitani, Luigi |title=Wolves: Behavior, Ecology, and Conservation|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=_mXHuSSbiGgC&pg=PA44|year= 2010|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-51698-1|pages=44–}}</ref> Ejaculation is induced by pelvic thrusting and undulation of the cervix. After the first ejaculation, the male lifts his leg over the female and faces the opposite direction. The male wolf usually ejaculates multiple times during copulation.<ref name="MobileReference2009">{{cite book|title=The Illustrated Encyclopedia of North American Mammals: A Comprehensive Guide to Mammals of North America|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=VxK4KWrGn2cC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=wolf%20ejaculate&f=false|year=2009|publisher=MobileReference|isbn=978-1-60501-279-7}}</ref>  Because estrus in wolves lasts only a month, male wolves do not abandon their mates to find other females to [[inseminate]] as dogs do.

[[File:Canis lupus arctos - Tiergarten Schönbrunn.jpg|thumb|Wolf pups, [[Tiergarten Schönbrunn]]]] During pregnancy, female wolves remain in a den located away from the peripheral zone of their territories, where violent encounters with other packs are more likely.<ref name="m42">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=42–46}}</ref> Old females usually [[Birth|whelp]] in the den of their previous litter, while younger females typically den near their birthplace. The [[gestation period]] lasts 62–75 days, with pups usually being born in the summer period.<ref name="s249">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=249}}</ref>
Wolves bear relatively large pups in small litters compared to other canid species.<ref name="m47">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=46–49}}</ref> The average litter consists of 5–6 pups,<ref name="m176">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=176}}</ref><ref name="g42">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|p=42}}</ref> with litter sizes tending to increase in areas where prey is abundant,<ref name="m176" /> though exceptionally large litters of 14–17 pups occur only 1% of the time.<ref name="g42" /> Pups are usually born in spring, coinciding with a corresponding increase in prey populations.<ref name="m42" /> Pups are born blind and deaf, and are covered in short soft grayish-brown fur. They weigh 300–500&nbsp;grams at birth, and begin to see after 9–12 days. The milk canines erupt after one month. Pups first leave the den after 3 weeks. At 1.5 months of age, they are agile enough to flee from danger. Mother wolves do not leave the den for the first few weeks, relying on the fathers to provide food for them and their young. Pups begin to eat solid food at the age of 3–4 weeks. Pups have a fast growth rate during their first four months of life: during this period, a pup's weight can increase nearly 30 times.<ref name="m47" /><ref name="s253">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|pp=253–54}}</ref> Wolf pups begin play fighting at the age of 3 weeks, though unlike young foxes and coyotes, their bites are inhibited. Actual fights to establish hierarchy usually occur at 5–8 weeks of age. This is in contrast to young foxes and coyotes, which may begin fighting even before the onset of play behavior.<ref name="fox1978">Fox, M. W. (1978). ''The Dog: Its Domestication and Behavior''. Garland STPM Press. pp. 21–40. ISBN 0824098587</ref> By autumn, the pups are mature enough to accompany adults on hunts for large prey.<ref name="m42" />{{clear}}

===Denning and sheltering behaviour===
Wolves use different places for their diurnal rest: places with cover are preferred during cold, damp and windy weather, while wolves in dry, calm and warm weather readily rest in the open. During the autumn-spring period, when wolves are more active, they willingly lie out in the open, whatever their location. Actual dens are usually constructed for pups during the summer period. When building dens, females make use of natural shelters such as fissures in rocks, cliffs overhanging riverbanks and holes thickly covered by vegetation. Sometimes, the den is the appropriated burrow of smaller animals such as foxes, badgers or marmots. An appropriated den is often widened and partly remade. On rare occasions, female wolves dig burrows themselves, which are usually small and short with 1–3 openings.<ref name="s234" /> Wolves do not line their denning places, a likely precaution against parasites.<ref name="ern760">{{Harvnb|Seton|1909|p=760}}</ref> The den is usually constructed not more than 500 metres away from a water source,<ref name="s234">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|pp=234–39}}</ref> and typically faces southwards, thus ensuring enough sunlight exposure, keeping the denning area relatively snow free.<ref name="f486">{{Harvnb|Feldhamer|Thompson|Chapman|2003|p=486}}</ref> Resting places, play areas for the pups and food remains are commonly found around wolf dens. The odour of urine and rotting food emanating from the denning area often attracts scavenging birds such as [[magpie]]s and [[raven]]s. As there are few convenient places for burrows, wolf dens are usually occupied by animals of the same family. Though they mostly avoid areas within human sight, wolves have been known to nest near [[Architecture|domiciles]], paved [[road]]s and [[railway]]s.<ref name="s234" />
[[File:Eastern wolves WSC.JPG|thumb|left|Captive wolves following hand gestures, Wolf Science Center, [[Austria]]]]

===Intelligence===
{{See also|Dog intelligence}}
Although the wolf's [[intelligence]] has not been quantified, scattered reports<ref name="mech8">{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|pp=8–9}}</ref> and laboratory studies<ref name="m63">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=63–65}}</ref> do give indications on the species' ability to remember, associate events, and learn.
During the extermination of the [[American bison]] on the [[Great Plains]], wolves learned to follow the sounds of gunshots, and would wait until the hunters had skinned and abandoned the bison carcasses before feeding on them. In northern Montana, where wolves were heavily persecuted by aerial hunters, wolves learned to avoid open areas whenever they heard aircraft. Conversely, biologists using aircraft to study wolves have managed to condition wolves not to fear their approach, even when flying low. When hunting, wolves tend to target the easiest options available to them: in areas populated by both [[moose]] and smaller [[deer]] species, the latter are taken in much higher proportion. The wolf's powers of memory were described by [[George Mivart]], who reported that a tame wolf was able to recognise its master after a three-year absence.<ref name="mech8" /> Non-rabid wolves are able to distinguish between armed and unarmed people,<ref name="s244">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|pp=244–245}}</ref> and typically avoid investigating people who display self-confident demeanors typical of being armed.<ref name="geist" /> Adult wolves have been known to skillfully select hidden approaches when entering their dens, using bushes, wind-fallen trees, stumps, and other natural structures to conceal their approach.<ref name="s244" /> Wolves with prior experience to traps may learn how to avoid or even harmlessly trigger them: in his hunt for the [[Lobo the King of Currumpaw|Currumpaw wolf]], naturalist [[Ernest Thompson Seton]] noted that his initial attempts at capturing it were unsuccessful, as the wolf would dig up and spring the traps, or ignore them altogether.<ref>{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=192}}</ref>
[[File:Lobo exposing the traps.png|thumb|''Lobo unearthing the traps'' (1898), [[Ernest Thompson Seton]]]]

Though wolves are trainable, they lack the same degree of tractability seen in dogs. They are generally not as responsive as dogs are to coercive techniques involving fear, aversive stimuli and force. Generally, far more work is required to obtain the same degree of reliability seen in most dogs. Even then, once a certain behavior has been repeated several times, wolves may get bored and ignore subsequent commands. Wolves are more responsive toward positive conditioning and rewards,<ref name="training">{{cite web | url= http://www.wolfpark.org/wolfdogs/Poster_section7.html| title= Are wolves and wolfdog hybrids trainable? | publisher= Wolf Park| accessdate= 2008-10-30 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080615124627/http://www.wolfpark.org/wolfdogs/Poster_section7.html |archivedate = 2008-06-15}}</ref> though simple praise is not sufficient as in most dogs.<ref name="training2" /> Unlike dogs, wolves tend to respond more to hand signals than voice.<ref name="training2">{{cite web | url= http://www.wolfpark.org/training/Example-1.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080210012443/http://www.wolfpark.org/training/Example-1.html |archivedate=February 10, 2008 | title= Wolf Training and Socialisation: Example #1 | publisher= Wolf Park| accessdate= 2008-10-30}}</ref> Most attempts to train wolves as [[working dog]]s have met with failure. German biologist Erik Zimen attempted to train his captive wolves as [[sled dog]]s, and although his wolves eventually accepted the harness and the need to pull the sled in a straight line, they were ultimately unreliable, as they fought for personal space, would ignore commands once tired, and were distracted by other wildlife.<ref name="z88">{{Harvnb|Zimen|1981|pp=88–90}}</ref> However, [[John James Audubon]] recorded an instance of a wolf being trained to hunt deer in [[Kentucky]],<ref>Audubon, John James & Bachman, John (1851), ''The viviparous quadrupeds of North America, Volume 2'', p. 130</ref> and [[Henry Wharton Shoemaker]] published a similar account of settlers in western and central [[Pennsylvania]] using wolves as hunting dogs.<ref>Shoemaker, Henry Warton (1917) ''Extinct Pennsylvania Animals: The panther and the wolf.-Pt. II. Black moose, elk, bison, beaver, pine marten, fisher, glutton, Canada lynx'', Altoona Tribune Publishing Company, pp. 24–25</ref> [[Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon|Buffon]] wrote in his ''Natural History'' of tamed wolves in [[Persia]] being trained to perform dances and tricks.<ref name="buffon">[[Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon|Buffon, Georges Louis Leclerc]] & Barr, J. S. (1797), ''[http://books.google.it/books?id=tAFTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA149 Barr's Buffon. Buffon's Natural History: History of the brute creation. Of the degeneration of animals]'', H. D. Symonds, pp. 145–158</ref>{{clear}}

===Hunting and feeding behaviours===
[[File:Canis lupus pack surrounding Bison.jpg|thumb|right|[[American Bison]] standing its ground, thereby increasing its chance of survival]]
Although social animals, single wolves or mated pairs typically have higher success rates in hunting than do large packs, with single wolves having occasionally been observed to kill large prey such as moose, [[bison]] and [[muskox]]en unaided.<ref name="m119">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=119–121}}</ref> A wolf hunt can be divided into five stages:

* '''Locating prey:''' The wolves travel in search of prey through their power of scent, chance encounter, and tracking. Wolves typically locate their prey by scent, though they must usually be directly downwind of it. When a breeze carrying the prey's scent is located, the wolves stand alert, and point their eyes, ears and nose towards their target. In open areas, wolves may precede the hunt with group ceremonies involving standing nose-to-nose and wagging their tails. Once concluded, the wolves head towards their prey.<ref name="mech196">{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|pp=196–199}}</ref>
* '''The stalk:''' The wolves attempt to conceal themselves as they approach.<ref name="g43">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|p=43}}</ref> As the gap between the wolves and their prey closes, the wolves quicken their pace, wag their tails, and peer intently, getting as close to their quarry as possible without making it flee.<ref name="mech199">{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|pp=199–200}}</ref>
* '''The encounter:''' Once the prey detects the wolves, it can either approach the wolves, stand its ground, or flee. Large prey, such as [[moose]], [[elk]], and muskoxen, usually stand their ground. Should this occur, the wolves hold back, as they require the stimulus of a running animal to proceed with an attack.<ref name="mech200">{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|pp=200–201}}</ref> If the targeted animal stands its ground, the wolves either ignore it, or try to intimidate it into running.<ref name="m119" />
* '''The rush:''' If the prey attempts to flee, the wolves immediately pursue it. This is the most critical stage of the hunt, as wolves may never catch up with prey running at top speed.<ref name="mech201">{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|pp=201–202}}</ref> If their prey is travelling in a group, the wolves either attempt to break up the herd, or isolate one or two animals from it.<ref name="g43" />
* '''The chase:''' A continuation of the rush, the wolves attempt to catch up with their prey and kill it.<ref name="mech202">{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|pp=202–203}}</ref> When chasing small prey, wolves attempt to catch up with their prey as soon as possible, while with larger animals, the chase is prolonged, in order to wear the selected prey out. Wolves usually give up chases after 1–2&nbsp;km (0.62–1.3&nbsp;mi), though one wolf was recorded to chase a deer for {{convert|21|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref name="m119" /> Both Russian and North American wolves have been observed to drive prey onto crusted ice, precipices, ravines, slopes and steep banks to slow them down.<ref name="g45" />
[[File:Wolves killing caribou.png|thumb||left|Killing a [[Caribou (North America)|caribou]] in typical fashion: biting the hindquarters (1909 drawing by [[Arthur Robert Harding|A. R. Harding]])]]

The actual killing method varies according to prey species. With large prey, mature wolves usually avoid attacking frontally, instead focusing on the rear and sides of the animal. Large prey, such as moose, is killed by biting large chunks of flesh from the soft [[perineum]] area, causing massive [[blood loss]]. Such bites can cause wounds 10–15&nbsp;cm in length, with three such bites to the perineum usually being sufficient to bring down a large deer in optimum health.<ref name="g45">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|p=45}}</ref> With medium-sized prey such as [[roe deer]] or [[sheep]], wolves kill by biting the throat, severing nerve tracks and the [[carotid artery]], thus causing the animal to die within a few seconds to a minute. With small, [[mouse]]-like prey, wolves leap in a high arc and imobilize it with their forepaws.<ref name="z217">{{Harvnb|Zimen|1981|pp=217–218}}</ref> When prey is vulnerable and abundant, wolves may occasionally [[surplus killing|surplus kill]]. Such instances are common in domestic animals, but rare in the wild. In the wild, surplus killing primarily occurs during late winter or spring, when snow is unusually deep (thus impeding the movements of prey)<ref>{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=144}}</ref> or during the denning period, when wolves require a ready supply of meat when denbound.<ref name="l54">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|pp=54–55}}</ref> Medium-sized prey are especially vulnerable to surplus killing, as the swift throat-biting method by which they are killed allows wolves to quickly kill one animal and move on to another.<ref name="z217" /> Surplus killing may also occur when adult wolves are teaching their young to hunt.<ref name="g67">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|p=67}}</ref>

Once prey is brought down, wolves begin to feed excitedly, ripping and tugging at the carcass in all directions, and bolting down large chunks of it.<ref name="mech185">{{Harvnb|Mech|1981|p=185}}</ref> The breeding pair typically monopolizes food in order to continue producing pups. When food is scarce, this is done at the expense of other family members, especially non-pups.<ref name="m58">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=58}}</ref> The breeding pair typically eats first, though as it is they who usually work the hardest in killing prey, they may rest after a long hunt and allow the rest of the family to eat unmolested. Once the breeding pair has finished eating, the rest of the family tears off pieces of the carcass and transport them to secluded areas where they can eat in peace. Wolves typically commence feeding by consuming the larger internal organs of their prey, such as the [[heart]], [[liver]], [[lungs]] and [[stomach]] lining. The [[kidneys]] and [[spleen]] are eaten once they are exposed, followed by the [[muscle]]s.<ref name="m123">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=122–5}}</ref> A single wolf can eat 15–19% of its body weight in a single feeding.<ref name="m201">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|pp=201}}</ref>

==Communication==
{{see also|Dog communication}}

===Visual===
[[File:Lorenz emotions.png|thumb|300px|Facial expressions ([[Konrad Lorenz]], 1952). ''bottom to top:'' increasing fear (ears back); ''left to right:'' increasing aggression (snarl); ''top right:'' maximum of both.]]
The gray wolf's expressive behavior is more complex than that of the coyote and golden jackal, as necessitated by its group living and hunting habits. While less gregarious canids generally possess simple repertoires of visual signals, wolves have more varied signals which subtly inter grade in intensity.<ref name="fox1978" /><ref name="z68">{{Harvnb|Zimen|1981|pp=68}}</ref> When neutral, the legs are not stiffened, the tail hangs down loosely, the face is smooth, the lips untensed, and the ears point in no particular direction.<ref name="z52">{{Harvnb|Zimen|1981|p=52}}</ref> Postural communication in wolves consists of a variety of facial expressions, tail positions and [[piloerection]].<ref name="l43">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=43}}</ref> Aggressive, or self-assertive wolves are characterized by their slow and deliberate movements, high body [[posture (psychology)|posture]] and raised [[hackles (animal)|hackles]], while submissive ones carry their bodies low, sleeken their fur and lower their ears and tail.<ref name="Mech 2003 90">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=90}}</ref> When a breeding male encounters a subordinate family member, it may stare at it, standing erect and still with the tails horizontal to its spine.<ref name="l44">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=44}}</ref> Two forms of submissive behavior are recognized: passive and active. Passive submission usually occurs as a reaction to the approach of a [[dominance (ethology)|dominant animal]], and consists of the submissive wolf lying partly on its back and allowing the dominant wolf to sniff its [[anogenital area]]. Active submission occurs often as a form of greeting, and involves the submissive wolf approaching another in a low posture, and licking the other wolf's face.<ref>{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=93}}</ref> When wolves are together, they commonly indulge in behaviors such as nose pushing, jaw wrestling, cheek rubbing and facial licking. The mouthing of each other's muzzles is a friendly gesture, while clamping on the muzzle with bared teeth is a dominance display.<ref name="l47">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=47}}</ref>

===Auditory===
[[File:Howlsnow.jpg|thumb|left|Howling wolf, [[UK Wolf Conservation Trust]]]]

====Howling====
{{Listen|filename=Wolf howls.ogg|title=Wolves howling|format=[[Ogg]]}}
{{Listen|filename=rallying.ogg|title=Rallying cry|format=[[Ogg]]}}
Wolves howl to assemble the pack (usually before and after hunts), to pass on an alarm (particularly at a den site), to locate each other during a storm or unfamiliar territory and to communicate across great distances.<ref name="l38" /> Wolf howls can under certain conditions be heard over areas of up to {{convert|130|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}.<ref name="f496">{{Harvnb|Feldhamer|Thompson|Chapman|2003|p=496}}</ref> Wolf howls are generally indistinguishable from those of large dogs.<ref name="ern770">{{Harvnb|Seton|1909|p=770}}</ref> Male wolves give voice through an [[octave]], passing to a deep [[Bass (sound)|bass]] with a stress on "''O''", while females produce a modulated nasal [[baritone]] with stress on "''U''". Pups almost never howl, while yearling wolves produce howls ending in a series of dog-like yelps.<ref name="s262">{{Harvnb|Heptner|Naumov|1998|p=262}}</ref> Howling consists of a fundamental frequency which may lie between 150 and 780&nbsp;Hz, and consists of up to 12 harmonically related overtones. The pitch usually remains constant or varies smoothly, and may change direction as many as four or five times.<ref name="mech" /> Howls used for calling pack mates to a kill are long, smooth sounds similar to the beginning of the cry of a [[horned owl]]. When pursuing prey, they emit a higher pitched howl, vibrating on two notes.
