These attacks were well documented by trained biologists.<ref name="lin26">{{Harvnb|Linnell|2002|p=26}}</ref> In [[Hazaribagh]], [[Bihar]], 100 children were injured and 122 killed from 1980 to 1986.<ref name="singh">{{cite journal|author=Rajpurohit, K.S.|year= 1999|title=Child lifting: Wolves in Hazaribagh, India|journal=Ambio |volume=28|pages=162–166}}</ref>

The North American continent has very few recorded incidences of such,<ref name="lin" /> though the [[oral history]] of some Native American tribes confirms that wolves occasionally did kill humans. Tribes living in woodlands feared wolves more than their tundra-dwelling counterparts, as they could encounter wolves suddenly and at close quarters.<ref name="l69">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|pp=69, 123}}</ref> It is thought that the reason why far fewer attacks are recorded in North America than in Eurasia is linked to the former's historically greater availability of [[firearms]], whose usage taught North American wolves to fear humans more than their Eurasian counterparts.<ref name="grisly185">{{Harvnb|Roosevelt|1909|p=185}}</ref><ref name="ern767">{{Harvnb|Seton|1909|p=767}}</ref><ref name="g8">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|p=8}}</ref> However, encounters with aggressive wolves in North America seem to be on the increase. One study revealed 80 events in Alaska and Canada where wolves closely approached or attacked people, finding 39 cases of aggression by apparently healthy wolves, and 29 cases of fearless behavior by nonaggressive wolves.<ref>McNay, Mark (2002) [http://www.wildlife.alaska.gov/pubs/techpubs/research_pdfs/techb13p1.pdf A Case History of Wolf-Human Encounters in Alaska and Canada], Alaska Department of Fish and Game Wildlife Technical Bulletin. Wildlife.alaska.gov. Retrieved on 2011-09-16.</ref> At least two fatal attacks by wild, non-rabid wolves have occurred in 21st century North America: in 2005, [[Kenton Joel Carnegie wolf attack|a man was killed]] in [[Saskatchewan]], [[Canada]],<ref>McNay, M. E. (2007) "A Review of Evidence and Findings Related to the Death of Kenton Carnegie on 8 November 2005 Near Points North, Saskatchewan". Alaska Department of Fish and Game, Fairbanks, Alaska.</ref> while in 2010, a woman was killed whilst jogging near [[Chignik Lake]] in [[Alaska]].<ref>Butler, L., B. Dale, K. Beckmen, and S. Farley. 2011.[http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/static/home/news/pdfs/wolfattackfatality.pdf Findings Related to the March 2010 Fatal Wolf Attack near Chignik Lake, Alaska]. Wildlife Special Publication, ADF&G/DWC/WSP-2011-2. Palmer, Alaska.</ref>

[[File:Provedenie meropriyatii po otstrelu vrednyh givotnyh na territorii Kamyshinskogo raiona Volgogradskoi oblasti.jpg|thumb|Carcasses of hunted wolves in [[Kamyshinsky District]], [[Volgograd Oblast]], [[Russia]].]]

===Hunting===
{{Main|Wolf hunting|Wolf hunting with dogs}}
Wolves are notoriously difficult to hunt due to their elusiveness, their sharp senses, their high endurance in the chase and ability to quickly incapacitate and kill hunting dogs.<ref name="grisly182">{{Harvnb|Roosevelt|1909|pp=182, 192}}</ref> Historically, many methods have been devised to hunt wolves,<ref name="hunt">{{Harvnb|Harding|1909|p=}}</ref><ref name="methods">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|pp=121–40}}</ref> including the killing of spring-born litters in their dens,<ref name="hunt65">{{Harvnb|Harding|1909|pp=65–75}}</ref> [[coursing]] with dogs (usually combinations of [[sighthound]]s, [[bloodhound]]s and [[fox terrier]]s),<ref name="hunt76">{{Harvnb|Harding|1909|pp=76–85}}</ref> poisoning with [[strychnine]],<ref name="hunt99">{{Harvnb|Harding|1909|pp=99–108}}</ref> and foothold<ref name="hunt109">{{Harvnb|Harding|1909|pp=109–23}}</ref> and [[deadfall trap]]s.<ref name="l108">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|p=108}}</ref> A popular method of wolf hunting in Russia involves trapping a pack within a small area by encircling it with [[fladry]] poles carrying a human scent. This method relies heavily on the wolf's fear of human scents, though it can lose its effectiveness when wolves become accustomed to the smell.<ref name="g121">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|p=121}}</ref> Some hunters are able to lure wolves by imitating their calls.<ref name="g122">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|p=122}}</ref> In [[Kazakhstan]] and [[Mongolia]], wolves are traditionally hunted with eagles and falcons, though this practise is declining, as experienced falconers are becoming few in number.<ref name="g124">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|p=124}}</ref> Shooting wolves from aircraft is highly effective, as it allows greater visibility of wolves than hunting on the ground,<ref name="g125">{{Harvnb|Graves|2007|pp=125–36}}</ref> though this method is controversial, as it allows wolves little chance to escape or defend themselves.<ref name="l159">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|pp=159–60}}</ref>{{clear}}

{{North American Game}}

===Uses===
[[File:BuffaloHunters.jpg|thumb|left|''Hunting Buffalo Camouflaged with Wolf Skins'' (1832), [[George Catlin]].]]
Wolf pelts are primarily used for [[scarf]]s and the [[Trim (sewing)|trimming]]s of women's garments, though they are occasionally used for [[jacket]]s, short [[cape]]s, [[coat (clothing)|coat]]s,<ref name="bach" /> [[mukluk]]s and [[Carpet|rugs]].<ref name="mech" /> Wolf pelts tend to be thinner than those of dogs, and are more prone to tearing when sewn.<ref name="c55">{{Harvnb|Coppinger|Coppinger|2001|p=55}}</ref> The quality of wolf peltries rests on the density and strength of the fur fibre, which keeps the fur upright and gives the pelt an appealing bushy aspect. These characteristics are mostly found in northern wolf populations, but gradually lessen further south in warmer climates. North American wolf pelts are among the most valuable, as they are silkier and fluffier than Eurasian peltries.<ref name="bach">{{cite book | author=Bachrach, M.| title=Fur: a practical treatise | year=1953 | pages=206–13 |  publisher=Prentice-Hall | location=New York}}</ref> The pelts of wolves killed by poison are mostly worthless.<ref name="hunt108">{{Harvnb|Harding|1909|p=108}}</ref> In [[Medieval Europe]], pelts were considered the only practical aspect of wolves, though they were seldom used, due to the skin's foul odour.<ref name="griff">{{cite book | author=Griffin, Emma| title=Blood sport: hunting in Britain since 1066 | year=2007 | page=65 | isbn=0-300-11628-4 | publisher=Yale University Press | location=}}</ref> In [[Scandinavian folklore]], wolf-skin [[girdle]]s assisted in transforming the wearers into werewolves,<ref>Woodward, Ian ''The Werewolf Delusion'' (1979) p. 121, Paddington Press Ltd. ISBN 0-448-23170-0</ref> while several Native American tribes used wolf pelts for medicinal purposes.<ref name="l108" /> [[Plains Indians]] often wore wolf pelts as disguises to get close to [[American bison]] when hunting.<ref name="buffalohuntpainting">{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsoniansource.org/display/primarysource/viewdetails.aspx?TopicId=1000&PrimarySourceId=1092|title=Buffalo Hunt Painting|publisher=Smithsonian Source|accessdate=2013-01-28}}</ref>

The [[Pawnee people|Pawnee]] wore wolf skins as capes when exploring enemy territories.<ref name="l111">{{Harvnb|Lopez|1978|pp=111–2}}</ref> The [[United States Army]] used wolf skin for [[parka]]s during the later stages of [[World War II]] and the [[Korean War]] to protect the faces of soldiers from [[frostbite]].<ref name="bach" /> In the [[Soviet Union]], 30,000 wolf pelts were produced annually between 1976 and 1988. Recent statistics from [[CITES]] indicate that 6,000–7,000 wolf skins are internationally traded each year, with [[Canada]], the former Soviet Union, Mongolia and [[China]] being the largest exporters, and the [[United States]] and [[Great Britain]] being the largest importers. Overall, the harvesting of wolves for their fur has little impact on their population, as only the northern varieties (whose numbers are stable) are of commercial value.<ref>{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=329}}</ref> Wolf trapping for fur remains a lucrative source of income for many Native Americans.<ref name="mech" />{{clear}}

[[File:Wolf Fox & Seal Skins in Norway.jpg|thumb|upright|Wolf skins at the [[Bergen]] fishmarket, Norway.]] 
It is rare for wolves to be hunted for food, though historically, people have resorted to consuming wolf flesh in times of scarcity, or for medicinal reasons. Wolf meat was eaten several times during [[Vilhjalmur Stefansson]]'s 1913 Arctic expedition, particularly during the summer, when wolves were fat.<ref>Steffanson, Vilhjamur (2004) ''My Life With The Eskimo'', Kessinger Publishing, p. 151, ISBN 1417923954</ref> Natives in [[Transbaikalia]] reportedly ate wolf meat even when food was plentiful.<ref name="cherassov94">Cherkassov, Alexander Alexandrovich (2012) ''Notes of an East Siberian Hunter'', Authorhouse, p. 94, ISBN 1468528971</ref> Most Native American tribes, particularly the [[Naskapi]]s, viewed wolf flesh as edible but inadequate nutrition, as it was not a herbivore and thus did not possess the same healing qualities thought to be distinct in plant eaters.<ref name="l111" /> The consumption of wolf flesh and organs plays an important role in Asian [[folk medicine]]: in [[Mongolia]], eating the meat and [[lungs]] of a wolf is said to alleviate colds, and sprinkling food with powdered wolf [[rectum]] is said to cure [[haemorroids]].<ref name="kohn">Kohn, Michael (2008) ''Mongolia'', [[Lonely Planet]], p. 50, ISBN 1741045789</ref> Some Japanese mountain people ate wolf meat to give them courage.<ref name="w32">{{Harvnb|Walker|2005|p=32}}</ref> During the filming of ''[[The Grey (film)|The Grey]]'', the cast members famously ate wolf meat.<ref name="latimes">{{Cite news|last=Lynch|first=Rene|title='The Grey' slammed for 'bloodthirsty' portrayal of wolves|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2012/01/the-grey-slammed-for-bloodthirsty-portrayal-of-wolves.html|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=29 January 2012|date=28 January 2012}}</ref> Accounts on how wolf meat tastes vary greatly, with descriptions ranging from "tough",<ref name="w32" /> "gristly",<ref name="grillo">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/51901/exclusive-interview-actor-frank-grillo-discusses-grey-complicated-bad-guys-eating-wolf-an|date=January 24, 2012 | title=Exclusive Interview: Actor Frank name="cherassov94" /> to "somewhat [resembling] [[chicken (food)|chicken]]",<ref>Jenness, Stuart Edward (2004), ''The Making Of An Explorer: George Hubert Wilkins And The Canadian Arctic Expedition, 1913–1916'', McGill-Queens, p. 159, ISBN 0773527982</ref> and "very superior to lean [[venison]]".<ref>Palliser, John (1853), ''Solitary rambles and adventures of a hunter in the prairies'', J. Murray, p. 172.</ref>

===Wolves as pets===
{{Main|Wolves as pets and working animals}}
Tame wolves tend to be less predictable and manageable than dogs,<ref name="m304">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=304}}</ref> as they lack any alteration of their predatory behaviour, and can thus not be fully trusted in situations where their [[prey drive]] can be given adequate stimulation.<ref name="d18" /> Wolves are generally easier to tame than other wild canids, as they maintain infant attachments to family members and owners much longer, and also form secondary attachments to strangers much more readily.<ref name="fox1978" /> However, in contrast to dogs, which are usually accepting of strangers throughout their lives, treating them almost as an extension of their pack, wolves become increasingly [[xenophobia|xenophobic]] and intolerant of strangers not part of their immediate pack as they age.<ref name="d18" /> Despite this, the keeping of wolves as pets has grown in popularity, with an estimated 80,000 to 2 million privately owned wolves being present in the USA alone.<ref name="m304" /> While dog pups still have the ability to be [[socialisation|socialised]] at up to ten weeks of age, nineteen days may be too long to wait to begin socializing a wolf pup.<ref name="c42">{{Harvnb|Coppinger|Coppinger|2001|p=42}}</ref> Because wolf milk contains more [[arginine]] than can be found in puppy [[milk substitute]]s, an arginine supplement is needed when feeding pups below the weaning age. Failure to do so can result in the pups developing [[cataract]]s.<ref name="m197">{{Harvnb|Mech|Boitani|2003|p=197}}</ref> While dogs readily, and actively form social bonds with humans, wolves can only do so in the absence of adult [[conspecifics]].<ref name="d20">{{Harvnb|Lindsay|2000|p=20}}</ref> Pups under one year of age are generally not aggressive toward strangers, though their aggression increases with age, particularly during the mating season. Males may be more aggressive and difficult to handle than females.<ref name="pavlov" /> Wolves are difficult to contain in standard [[kennel]]s, as they exceed dogs in [[observational learning]] and are able to quickly learn how to undo [[latch (hardware)|latch]]es by simply watching their handlers do so.<ref name="c46">{{Harvnb|Coppinger|Coppinger|2001|pp=46–7}}</ref> Once wolves learn how to escape confinement, it becomes nearly impossible to contain them.<ref name="d19">{{Harvnb|Lindsay|2000|p=19}}</ref>
